name: Tomatoes
details: Juicy, flavorful fruits in various sizes and colors. Indeterminate varieties continue producing throughout the season.
instructions: Start seeds indoors 6-8 weeks before last frost. Transplant seedlings when soil warms. Provide sturdy stakes or cages for support.
water: Deep, consistent watering, especially during fruiting.
diseases: Blossom end rot, blight, bacterial wilt.
solutions: Maintain consistent soil moisture, avoid overhead watering, remove affected foliage, consider resistant varieties.
fertilizers: Balanced fertilizer at planting, then lower-nitrogen fertilizer once fruiting begins.

name: Cucumbers
details: Refreshing, crisp fruits. Choose bush varieties for smaller spaces or vining varieties for higher yields.
instructions: Direct sow seeds after last frost or start indoors. Provide trellis or support for vining types.
water: Consistent moisture, especially important during flowering and fruiting.
diseases: Powdery mildew, downy mildew, cucumber mosaic virus.
solutions: Proper spacing for air circulation, avoid overhead watering, use fungicides if necessary, choose disease-resistant varieties.
fertilizers: Balanced fertilizer at planting, side-dress with compost during the season.

name: Peppers
details: Sweet or spicy varieties in a range of colors and shapes.
instructions: Start seeds indoors 8-10 weeks before last frost. Transplant seedlings when soil warms.
water: Deep, regular watering, especially during flowering and fruiting.
diseases: Blossom end rot, bacterial spot, viruses.
solutions: Maintain consistent soil moisture, remove affected foliage, choose disease-resistant varieties.
fertilizers: Balanced fertilizer at planting, side-dress with compost during the season.

name: Beans (Bush)
details: Tender, flavorful pods. Harvest regularly to encourage continued production.
instructions: Direct sow seeds after last frost. Plant in succession for an extended harvest.
solutions: Proper spacing, avoid overhead watering, choose disease-resistant varieties.
fertilizers: Usually don't need fertilizer as they fix nitrogen in the soil.
